    • Rinzai 128  is a modern and fully customizable Zendesk theme built to elevate your Help Center and Knowledge Base. Powered by Templating API v4, it offers advanced flexibility, seamless design control, and includes the AI Quick Answers feature to boost customer support efficiency.
  • Zemplate (Support) (paid)
    • Zemplate is a no-code email template designer. Change colors, spaces, borders and more with simple input and slider controls. Add logos, banners, and more to the header, footer, or background of your emails.  Copy the generated code into the email template settings in the Admin Centre.
  • Zendesk for Contact Center Dashboards (Support)
    • Zendesk for Contact Center Dashboards gives you seamless access to your contact center’s core performance metrics and reporting - all in real time and within the familiar Zendesk environment.  Gain immediate visibility into real-time and historical contact center metrics.  Access all four Zendesk for Contact Center dashboards directly within Zendesk.  Monitor agent and team performance effortlessly to make timely, informed decisions.
  • Bucky (Theme)
    • Bucky is a sleek and intuitive Zendesk theme built for easy customization. With powerful built-in settings, you can fully brand your Help Center—no coding needed. Created in honor of the greatest husky, it’s as bold and reliable as its namesake.
  • Trigger Analyzer 2025 (Support) (paid)
    • Trigger Analyzer 2025 analyzes your trigger setups, tells you why it fired (or not), and the impact of changes.  Trigger Analyzer 2025 gives you full visibility into your trigger logic, dependencies, and what might happen if you change it. Whether you're building something new, debugging something broken, or trying to understand what's going on, Trigger Analyzer helps you do it without fear.

Products with no updates this week

  • Talk
  • Admin Center
  • Zendesk Workforce Management (WFM)
  • Mobile
  • Explore
  • Zendesk QA

articles.name: Explore recipe: Tracking sentiment and intent changes in tickets
articles.title: Explore recipe: Tracking sentiment and intent changes in tickets
articles.body:
What's my plan?
Add-on Copilot

In this Explore recipe, you’ll learn how to create a report to monitor and compare how ticket sentiment or intent changes throughout the ticket lifecycle.

This article contains the following topics:

  • What you’ll need
  • Reporting on ticket sentiment or intent changes

What you’ll need

Skill level: Beginner

Time required: 5 minutes

  • Zendesk Copilot add-on
  • Intelligent triage turned on and configured (see Automatically detecting customer intent, sentiment, and language)
  • Dynamic detection turned on for sentiment and intent
  • Ticket intent or sentiment data in Zendesk Support
  • Editor or Admin permissions (see Giving users access to Explore)

Reporting on ticket sentiment or intent changes

You can create a report to view how sentiment or intent evolves in tickets over time. 

To report on ticket sentiment or intent changes 

  1. In Explore, click the reports () icon.
  2. In the Reports library, click New report.
  3. On the Select a dataset page, click Support > Support - Updates history, then click Start report.
    The report builder opens.
  4. Next, add your metrics, the things you want to measure. In this case, you’ll add the number of tickets updated. In the Metrics panel, click Add.
  5. From the list of metrics, choose Tickets > Tickets updated, then click Apply.
  6. In the Columns panel, click Add.
  7. From the list of attributes, choose the following:
    • Tickets fields changes > Changes - Field Name
    • Changes - Previous value
    • Changes - New value
  8. Click Apply.
  9. In the Filters panel, add a filter for Changes - Field Name. Set the filter to include one of the following:
    • Sentiment
    • Intent

  10. Click Apply.
  11. From the Visualizations menu (), choose Table.

  12. Give your report a meaningful name for future reference and then click Save.
    The screenshot below shows an example of what your report will look like when it’s completed when you select the sentiment filter. The table displays how many tickets experienced each type of sentiment.

articles.name: Release notes through 2025-06-13
articles.title: Release notes through 2025-06-13
articles.body:
See our What's New for an overview of what was released last month.

This week's release notes include:

  • AI Agents and Knowledge
  • Copilot
  • Zendesk Workforce Management (WFM)
  • Mobile
  • Products with no updates this week

AI Agents and Knowledge

New:
  • Added a new public API to list CSAT responses.

Copilot

New:

  • Intelligent triage:

    • Intent model improvements to better capture the intent changes in each account and use them to influence the predictions.

Zendesk Workforce Management (WFM)

Fixed:

Forecast

  • Export for inbound volume and required staffing: The export now reflects only the selected workstreams for the selected interval.

Mobile

Android

New:

  • Android 16 support: The SDK is now fully compatible with Android 16, aligning with the latest updates and platform requirements from Google.
  • Support for retrieving unread message count for a specific conversation: You can now pass a conversation ID to getUnreadMessageCount() to retrieve unread counts for a specific conversation. Learn more in the API documentation. 

Fixed:

  • Fixed an issue where a new conversation could be created unexpectedly after tapping the back button from a full-screen image view.
  • Fixed a crash when displaying help center articles by replacing a call to an unsupported OkHttp method with a standard Kotlin utility.
  • Fixed a crash that occurred when uploading an attachment after opening a conversation via a push notification.
  • Fixed an issue where old proactive message IDs were incorrectly reused after starting a new conversation.
  • Improved the behavior of Zendesk.invalidate() to fully clean up SDK resources and prevent memory leaks.

iOS

Fixed:

  • Fixed an issue where tapping to retry after reestablishing a connection caused an infinite loading spinner.
  • Resolved RTL (Right-to-Left) language display issues relating to rich text displayed by the bot.
  • Corrected the unread counter behavior when "canUserSeeConversationList" was set to false, ensuring accurate unread message counts.
  • Fixed a bug with handling file names containing spaces.
  • Addressed event ordering issues, ensuring events appear in the correct sequence.
  • Fixed a bug to invoke a delegate for all guide article URLs, enabling custom URL handling.
  • Adjusted the width of the ThumbsDown button to prevent it from appearing too wide.

Products with no updates this week

  • Support
  • Chat and messaging
  • Talk
  • Admin Center
  • Explore
  • Zendesk QA

articles.name: Scheduled Maintenance - July 9-10, 2025 | Pod 13 | Zendesk Messaging & Sunshine Conversations
articles.title: Scheduled Maintenance - July 9-10, 2025 | Pod 13 | Zendesk Messaging & Sunshine Conversations
articles.body:
Zendesk will perform critical maintenance which will impact performance for notified customers on Pod 13 from July 9-10, 2025, during the times listed below.

Affected products: Messaging & Sunshine Conversations

Important: Impacted customers (account owner and all admins) will receive a yellow notification banner in Support on Month Day. Only customers who have been notified and have Messaging enabled will be impacted, based on the Pod maintenance dates and timings below.
Customers Affected: Zendesk Messaging and Sunshine Conversations customers on Pod 13 who have been notified, will experience a brief service disruption of 40 minutes at some time within the 40 minute maintenance window.

Expected behavior: During the maintenance window, notified accounts attempting to use Messaging will find their accounts locked and unable to send outbound messages and instead will receive an HTTP 423 response. Messages sent by end-users via social messaging channels for these accounts will be preserved and buffered until the account is unlocked.

What do customers have to do? If customers have have enabled their own client-side Content Security Policy than they must include *.zendesk.com on their allowlist to ensure that their integrations continue to initialize and function.

Why we're doing this: The Zendesk Messaging team is rehoming customers accounts to be located in the same data store as their Support accounts increased reliability, performance & data locality.

articles.name: Why are emails missing from some end-user profiles?
articles.title: Why are emails missing from some end-user profiles?
articles.body:
Question

Why are emails missing from some end-user profiles?

Answer

When you use the Web Widget with JWT authentication, the email_verified parameter in the authentication must be true.

When this field is undefined and no email is given, a duplicate profile is created. To solve this, you can merge duplicates. For details, see: Merging a user's duplicate account.
